intro: Dasymaschalon coelophloeum, commonly known as the golden sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants commonly known as buckwheats. The plant is characterized by its sprawling growth habit, with hairy stems and small, clustered flowers that range in color from yellow to red. Its leaves are typically narrow and covered in fine hairs, adapted to reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. The plant produces small, wind-dispersed seeds, which contribute to its ability to colonize disturbed or sandy soils.
